questions.text: Dialysis is not an absolute indication for patients who present with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Dialysis is not indicated in patients who initially present with hyperkalemia. It is indicated in the case of refractory hyperkalemia that has failed to respond to other modalities of treatment.

Indications for dialysis can be remembered using the mnemonic AEIOU:

  • Acidosis - metabolic acidosis that is refractory to medical treatment.
  • Electrolyte abnormality - refractory hyperkalemia and hypercalcemia.
  • Intoxication - barbiturates, alcohol, and lithium.
  • Overload - hypervolemia and pulmonary edema.
  • Uncontrolled hypertension (and)
  • Uremia - encephalopathy, pericarditis, asterixis, seizures, intractable nausea and vomiting, and bleeding diathesis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most commonly used therapeutic modality for patients with end-stage renal disease?
questions.solution:
The most common therapeutic modality for patients with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) is hemodialysis.

The various modalities of renal replacement therapy include the following:

  • Dialysis:
    • Acute intermittent hemodialysis
    • Continuous renal replacement therapy - includes hemodialysis and ultrafiltration techniques
    • Peritoneal dialysis
      • CAPD - Continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis
      • CCPD - Continuous cycling peritoneal dialysis
      • NIPD - Nocturnal intermittent peritoneal dialysis
  • Renal transplant

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about hemodialysis?​

choices.text: Dialyzers are made up of cellulose membranes
Bicarbonate is commonly used as a buffer
Glutaraldehyde  is used as a reprocessing agent
Urea is cleared more efficiently than creatinine

questions.solution:
In hemodialysis, the dialyzer is made up of biocompatible membranes derived from polysulfone. Cellulose is bio-incompatible and is no longer used.

Hemodialysis is based on the principle of solute diffusion using an artificial semi-permeable membrane. Smaller molecules (urea) diffuse faster and are cleared more efficiently than larger molecules (creatinine). There are three components to this system:

  • Dialyzer - a chamber that contains compartments for blood and dialysate solution, separated by a semipermeable membrane. 
  • Dialysate - a solution that helps in the removal of metabolic waste products. Bicarbonate is used as a buffer to correct acidosis in CKD patients.
  • Blood delivery system - consists of the vascular access and extracorporeal circuit.

The dialyzers used during a session of dialysis are reprocessed and reused for the next dialysis sessions. The reprocessors used for dialyzers are: 

  • Glutaraldehyde
  • Formaldehyde  
  • Peracetic acid-hydrogen peroxide

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with stage 5 chronic kidney disease is planned for hemodialysis. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the vascular access for this procedure?

choices.text: Tunneled catheters are associated with lower infection rates
Access of choice is radiocephalic arteriovenous fistula
Most common complication of arteriovenous grafts is infection
Fistulas have higher long term patency rates

questions.solution:
The most common complication of arteriovenous (AV) grafts is stenosis, not infections.

In order to perform hemodialysis, vascular or hemodialysis access must first be established. The preferred site is the forearm. The following types of vascular access may be used for hemodialysis:

  • AV fistulas:
    • Fistula refers to the anastomosis of an artery and an adequately large vein (either side-to-side or end-to-side).
    • This causes arterialization of the vein, thereby causing venous wall thickening and increasing venous diameter.
    • Fistulas need 4-6 weeks to mature before they can be used. 
    • The access of choice is radiocephalic AV fistula (Brescia-Cimino fistula).
    • Fistulas have higher long-term patency rates than grafts.
    • Thrombosis is a common complication.

The following image depicts a radiocephalic fistula.

  • AV grafts:
    • The artery and vein are connected by a prosthetic graft such as PTFE (polytetrafluoroethylene).
    • The advantage is that it can be performed with smaller veins.
    • Complications include stenosis (most common), due to intimal hyperplasia at anastomosis between graft and vein, and infections.
  • Central venous catheter:
    • Tunneled catheters are used for long-term IV access. As they tunnel through the skin before entering the vein, they have a lower risk of infection.

questions.text: What is the rate of blood flow in the hemodialysis machine?
questions.solution: During hemodialysis, heparinized blood flows through the dialyzer at a rate of 250–450 mL/min. On the other hand, the dialysate flows in the opposite counter-current direction at 500–800 mL/min.

questions.text: In a patient undergoing hemodialysis, which of the following can be used to monitor the adequacy of dialysis?
questions.solution:
The adequacy of dialysis is determined by the urea reduction ratio. It is defined as the fractional reduction in blood urea nitrogen per hemodialysis session. It is calculated as (Co - C) / Co, where:

Co - predialysis serum urea

C - postdialysis serum urea

The target urea reduction ratio is 65–70%.

questions.text: Which of the following has been most commonly implicated as a cause of dialysis-induced hypotension in patients?
questions.solution:
Acetate is used as a buffer in the dialysate solution. It is the most common cause of dialysis-induced hypotension because of its vasodilatory and cardio-depressive effects.

For this reason, acetate is less commonly used these days and has been largely replaced by bicarbonate.

questions.text: What is the most common acute complication in patients who undergo hemodialysis?
questions.solution:
Hypotension is the most common acute complication of hemodialysis, particularly among patients with diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man is brought to the casualty following a seizure episode. His wife says that he has been very drowsy and has not passed urine for the past 2 days. Investigations reveal serum urea of 71 mg/dl and creatinine of 5.6 mg/dl. He is referred for urgent hemodialysis. You would take all of the following precautions except:

choices.text: Removing more fluid during the beginning than the end of the procedure
Maintaining fluid removal rate below 13 mL/kg/hour

questions.solution:
Cooling, not warming, the dialysate before dialysis must be done to prevent hypotension during dialysis.

Hypotension is the most common acute complication of hemodialysis. The mechanism is not fully understood and occurs due to multiple factors. However, the following precautions have been shown to frequently prevent this complication:

  • Careful calculation of the dry weight and adjustment of the filtration rate accordingly.
  • Ultrafiltration modeling such that more fluid is removed during the beginning than the end of the procedure.
  • Avoiding rapid fluid removal and maintaining the rate < 13 mL/kg/hour.
  • Avoiding heavy meals during dialysis.
  • Cooling of the dialysate during the dialysis.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman with CKD underwent her first session of hemodialysis. Towards the end of the session, she became drowsy and had a sudden seizure episode. What is the likely cause for this presentation?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of the dialysis disequilibrium syndrome or the reverse urea effect. It is an acute complication that occurs especially in patients undergoing dialysis for the first time.

During dialysis, urea in blood vessels is rapidly removed as compared to that in the interstitium. This decreases the osmolality of blood. This results in a fluid shift from the blood vessels into the interstitium and brain parenchyma, causing cerebral edema. 

In order to prevent this, the rate of flow of dialysate must be adjusted to avoid the rapid removal of solutes.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about anaphylaxis associated with hemodialysis?

choices.text: Occur due to lack of cellulose in the membranes
Ethylene oxide is the cause of Type B reaction
Dialysis is discontinued in Type A reaction
Type A reaction associated with complement activation

questions.solution:
Dialysis must be discontinued immediately in case of a type A reaction. It is an IgE-mediated immediate hypersensitivity reaction that can lead to shock and death.

Bio-incompatible cellulose-containing membranes are commonly associated with hemodialysis-associated anaphylaxis.

The reactions can be of two types:

Type A reaction  Type B reaction
IgE-mediated immediate hypersensitivity reaction in response to ethylene oxide. (used to sterilize dialyzers). Delayed reaction due to complement activation and cytokine release.
Occur within minutes. Occur after hours.

Stop dialysis and give subcutaneous adrenaline or steroids.

  It is self-limiting and dialysis can be continued.

questions.text: A patient on hemodialysis may develop all of the following chronic complications except:
questions.solution:
Hypovolemia is an acute complication of hemodialysis. The chronic complications of hemodialysis are:

  • Amyloidosis
  • Adynamic bone disease
  • Dementia (aluminum toxicity)

questions.text: A physician is evaluating a patient with carpal tunnel syndrome. He has been undergoing dialysis for the past 7 years. Deposition of which of the following is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Carpal tunnel syndrome in the setting of chronic dialysis is suggestive of dialysis-associated amyloidosis. It occurs due to the deposition of amyloid ß-2 in tissues.

This condition is seen in patients undergoing long-term hemodialysis or continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (CAPD). Amyloid deposition can lead to the following complications:

  • Destructive osteoarthropathies - carpal tunnel syndrome, flexor tenosynovitis
  • Subchondral bone cysts and pathologic fractures
  • Paraplegia - due to deposits along paravertebral ligaments and intervertebral discs
  • Visceral involvement - GI tract, heart, tongue

Management involves providing symptomatic relief by means of analgesics, anti-inflammatory drugs, physical and occupational therapy, and surgical procedures. Renal transplantation is the treatment of choice.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man is referred urgently for management of pulmonary edema. He was diagnosed with stage-5 CKD 3 weeks ago but was reluctant to start dialysis. On examination, he is confused and has a flapping tremor. Investigations are as follows. Which of his clinical features will not improve with dialysis?

Serum urea - 99 mg/dl

Serum creatinine - 5.1 mg/dl

Serum calcium - 7.1 mg/dl

Arterial blood gas - Metabolic acidosis
questions.solution:
Renal osteodystrophy does not show improvement with dialysis.

Failure of renal function leads to decreased renal vitamin D production. The resulting hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia, in turn, lead to secondary hyperparathyroidism. This can be corrected only by vitamin D and calcium supplementation.

Other manifestations of renal dysfunction and uremia show improvement with regular dialysis sessions.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of death in patients undergoing chronic dialysis?
questions.solution:
Cardiovascular disease due to accelerated atherosclerosis is the major cause of death in patients with ESRD on chronic dialysis.

Cardiovascular mortality is higher in dialysis patients compared to patients after transplantation.

questions.text: You are educating a patient about performing peritoneal dialysis at home. During this process, how much fluid is infused into the peritoneum?
questions.solution:
In peritoneal dialysis, 1.5–3 L of dialysis fluid is infused into the peritoneal cavity. 

In this process, the peritoneum itself acts as a semipermeable membrane. A peritoneal catheter is used to infuse the fluid into the cavity. It is allowed to dwell for a set period of time usually 2–4 hours to allow for the removal of metabolic waste products. The dialysis fluid contains osmotically active agents such as glucose or icodextrin.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with fever and severe abdominal pain for 2 days. He has been on peritoneal dialysis for the past 1 year. On examination, there is abdominal distension, guarding, and rebound tenderness. Which of the following is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario in a patient undergoing peritoneal dialysis is suggestive of peritonitis. It is most commonly caused by gram-positive cocci such as Staphylococcus, which spread from the skin.

questions.text: A woman is started on continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis. Which of the following complications is she unlikely to develop?
questions.solution:
Weight gain is a complication of peritoneal dialysis, not weight loss. The complications of peritoneal dialysis include:

  • Peritonitis
  • Catheter-associated non-peritonitis infections 
  • Weight gain
  • Metabolic disturbances - hypoproteinemia and hyperglycemia
  • Residual uremia - especially among patients with no residual kidney function
  • Insulin resistance
  • Hypertriglyceridemia

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about renal transplants?

choices.text: ABO and HLA mismatch are relative contraindications
Contraindicated in overt AIDS and active hepatitis
Complications in donor include hypertension and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis
The most common cause of death after renal transplant is infections

questions.solution:
The most common cause of death in renal transplant recipients is cardiovascular causes. It occurs in > 50% of patients.

Other complications in recipients include:

  • Infections 
    • Most common - CMV.
    • Most specific - BK (polyoma) virus
    • Most common fungal - pneumocystis.
  • Malignancy - most commonly of skin and lip

Donors can develop long-term complications related to premature failure of the single remaining kidney including:

  • Hypertension
  • Proteinuria
  • Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)

ABO and HLA mismatch are relative, not absolute contraindications due to the availability of desensitization procedures. The absolute contraindications for transplantation are as follows:

Recipient Donor
Any active infections/ malignancy Any active infections (including HIV)/ malignancy
Shortened life expectancy due to other causes Uncontrolled diabetes/ hypertension
Active substance abuse/ uncontrolled psychiatric condition Uncontrolled psychiatric condition or suicidality
Treatment nonadherence Age < 18 or lack of mental capacity
Reversible renal failure

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about rejection reactions following a kidney transplant?

choices.text: Acute rejection can occur due to both type 4 and type 2 hypersensitivity reactions
Hyperacute rejection is a type 2 hypersensitivity reaction
Induction therapy for prophylaxis of rejection is cyclosporine, azathioprine, prednisolone.
Alemtuzumab  is  monoclonal antibody against CD52 used for immunosuppression

questions.solution:
Cyclosporine, azathioprine, prednisolone constitute the prophylactic maintenance therapy used after renal transplant.

Immunosuppressive therapy is given to reduce the risk of transplant rejection reactions. The following regimen is commonly followed:

  • Induction therapy:
    • Given at the time of transplant to reduce the risk of early acute rejection.
    • The preferred treatment is anti-lymphocyte serum and alemtuzumab.
  • Maintenance therapy: 
    • Given to all kidney transplant patients except when the donor and recipient are identical twins.
    • The most common combination used is :
      cyclosporine, azathioprine, and prednisolone (also known as triple therapy).
    • Belatacept is a co-stimulatory blocking antibody approved by the FDA for maintenance therapy.

Rejection reactions can be hyperacute, acute, or chronic. Treatment of rejection is as follows:

  • First episode - IV prednisolone for 3 days
  • Failure to respond to prednisone or second episode - anti-thymocyte globulin

Related Pearl: Classification of Transplant Rejection Reactions

Hyperacute rejection (minutes to hours):

  • Mechanism: Antidonor antibodies present in the circulation of the recipient
  • Histopathological findings:
    • Grossly, cyanotic and mottled graft with pale white areas
    • Neutrophils accumulate
    • Acute fibrinoid necrosis of vessel walls or complete occlusion by thrombi

Acute rejection (days to weeks):

  1. Acute cellular rejection (acute T cell-mediated rejection):  
    • Mechanism: CD8+ CTLs directly destroy graft or CD4+ cells secrete cytokines that damage graft.
    • Histopathological findings:
      • Tubulointerstitial pattern (type I): extensive interstitial and tubular inflammation associated with focal tubular injury
      • Vascular pattern - Inflammation (type II) and necrosis (type III): Endotheliitis (swollen endothelial cells with lymphocytes between endothelium and vessel wall)
  2. Acute antibody-mediated (humoral) rejection: 
    • Mechanism: antibodies bind to endothelium and activate complement causing damage and graft failure
    • Histopathological findings:
      • Inflammation of glomeruli and peritubular capillaries.
      • Activation of the antibody-dependent classical complement pathway.
      • Focal thrombosis in small vessels. 

Chronic rejection (months to years):

  • Mechanism: T-cells react against alloantigens and secrete cytokines which stimulate fibroblasts and vascular smooth muscle cells (graft arteriosclerosis). Chronic rejection may also be antibody-mediated.
  • Histopathological findings:
    • Predominantly vascular changes (intimal thickening and vascular occlusion)
    • Glomerulopathy with duplication of basement membrane
    • Interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy with loss of renal parenchyma

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with polycystic kidney disease underwent renal transplantation 3 months ago. Which of the following infections is he at the highest risk of?
questions.solution:
The most common opportunistic infection occurring 1-6 months after renal transplant is Cytomegalovirus (CMV).

questions.text: Which of the following lesions does not recur in the transplanted kidney?
questions.solution:
Alport syndrome does not recur in the transplanted kidney. This is because it occurs due to an inherited defect in type 4 collagen in the glomerular basement membrane. This defect is absent in the transplanted kidney. 

Diabetic nephropathy, membranous glomerulonephritis, and lupus nephritis can recur in the transplanted kidney.

questions.text: Patients with which of the following conditions have the highest risk of disease recurrence after renal transplant?
questions.solution:
Patients with diabetic nephropathy have the highest risk of disease recurrence after renal transplant. Nearly 52% of transplant recipients have histological evidence of diabetic kidney disease/mesangial sclerosis at 10 years after transplantation.

The recurrence rates of the other conditions are as follows:

  • Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis: 20-48%
  • Membranous glomerulonephritis: 10-45%
  • Lupus nephritis: 2-11%

questions.text: What is the average life expectancy in patients following a living-donor kidney transplant?
questions.solution: The average life expectancy of a living-donor graft is around 14 years and that of a deceased-donor graft is around 10 years.
